Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The process starts with Receive order. Then Check inventory must come next. After that, if inventory is sufficient, the next steps are Authorize Payment > Package items > Ship order > Close order. If inventory isn't enough, after Check inventory comes Cancel order followed immediately by Close order.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The rules are that: Authorize Payment must be after Check inventory but before Packaging. Packaging before Ship. Close order must be last in all scenarios. Deviations such as shipping after cancellation, authorizing payment before checking inventory, or packaging before authorization would indicate violations.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 1: Receive, Check, Authorize, Package, Ship, Close. This sequence aligns perfectly with the normative process for sufficient inventory. No violation detected.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 2: The sequence is Receive, Check, Package. This skips Authorize payment after Check inventory and directly proceeds to Package items, violating the rule that payment authorization must occur before packaging.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 3: The sequence is Receive, Check, Authorize, Cancel, Ship, Close. Ship order occurs after Cancel order, which violates the rule that no further fulfillment activities can happen after cancellation. Close order must immediately follow cancellation.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 4: The sequence is Receive, Check, Cancel, Close. This is consistent with the normative process when inventory is insufficient. No violations detected.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 5: The sequence is Receive, Check, Authorize, Ship, Close. It skips the Package items step before Ship order, violating the rule that packaging must precede shipment.
